I ordered the gruyere mac n' cheese and the sliders. It was like comfort food went to college because it's classic American dishes but with an elegant flare. I was supposed to be at a concert at the Fillmore but I ended up not coming in until the opening acts were over because the food was that good! I didn't want to rush the experience.

The one downside is the wait. I think it would have been more bearable if I ordered a drink like the person next to me, but it was too cold to wait outside so I awkwardly placed myself right beside a set of light switches, which I accidentally turned off at one point. My apologies to all the patrons for that second of non-visual dining experience.

Try it yourself! Even picky eaters will love :D
author: Amy R.

description:
Nice spot for fun/different beers, I assume the wine selection is good.

Food is great, we tried all sorts of things and split them.  Food is pretty reasonably priced (~10 bucks for 3 sliders), some of the beers are crazy expensive.

Three of us had:

several great beers, including:
Ale Industries Rye'd Piper
Ale Industries Dualing Rye I believe it was called, cask aged
Arrogant Bastard Casked

Tried two appetizers:
Pretzel
Polenta fries  :--very good

Tried three "plates":
Sliders  :-- very tasty, light on the meat but very good.
Pesto Flat bread pizze   :--very good
Chicken Pot pie  :---  we were stuffed at this point, but it was excellent.  Probably second to The Townshead across town for chicken pot pies, but very good.  

Highly recommend the place.  it is small and crowded, takes about 30 minutes to get a seat inside.  has heaters on the outside for sitting or waiting.  We sat outside and started on beers and pretzel and were inside before we finished the pretzel.

Great starter for a night at the Fillmore.
author: Steve B.

description: Wine on draft and a chill atmosphere for happy hour?  I'm all over it!!! After walking by this bar on my way to State Bird Provisions last year, it was bustling and I've been wanting to try it ever since. I came here yesterday after work with my friend Will. The staff is friendly and bar has a cozy bistro feeling. The happy hour specials are $2 off wine and beer, $1 off the flatbreads. We had a half bottle of the draft Zinfandel (juicy and smooth), a half bottle of the draft Sauvignon Blanc (crisp and refreshing) and the wild mushroom and truffle oil flatbread (delish!). The place filled up quickly and was crackin'! They even had a large antler taxidermy on the back wall next to their chalkboard, which had a catchy saying from Hemingway and list of 8 beers on draft. I was really impressed with Fat Angel and have a new happy hour spot! :)
author: Kaila Y.

description: This place has outdoor seating and a bit of space indoors. Honestly, the beer selection is ridonk. They're categorized and organized in a way that will appeal to anyone - yeasty, hoppy, bitter, sour, reserves, etc. They also have wines on draft, and their draft beers rotate too. It's definitely a little pricey, but the ambiance is great. Sit and chill on a nice day with your friends while eating their fantastic mac n'cheese or polenta fries (both are amazing; you'll thank me later). Oh, and they play The Gaslight Anthem, The Decemberists, and Death Cab. Fantastic music selection. I do wish it were less pricey, and that there were more than just one unisex restroom.
author: Danny C.

description:
Open late which is great, and they have very friendly and knowledgeable service. We ordered a lot of food. Here's a roundup: The polenta fries are super delicious, definitely get these. We also got the sliders and the mac and cheese. The mac and cheese was good but pretty heavy. The chicken pot pie was massive and pretty good. All of the food tasted like it had just been prepared, which is a plus. Cautionary word - the food is super hot (temperature wise), so be careful otherwise you'll end up with a burned tongue. 

The creme brulee was a bit too eggy for my liking. 3.5 stars, but more of a 3 than a 4.
author: Ruchi M.

description: Great atmosphere. Excellent selection of wine,  beer and cocktails. Just stopped by for drinks, but we'll have to come back and check out their food. From the menu and seeing other people's meals it looks and smells delicious.
author: Joseph K.

description: Attn beer lovers.. Expansive beer selection! Nice intimate place in the neighborhood.  Modest selection of food. A little above average in pricing.  Great place for a date or small get together where you want to actually be able to hear the people you are with, and share some good quality food and drinks.  Mostly evening hours. Get there early to avoid a long wait.
author: Mel D.

description:
First of all, the apple bread pudding is a must order!! I'm a big fan of bread puddings and this could possibly be the best I've ever had. There's speculation at our table that the bread in the pudding is actually (gasp...) donuts!! Regardless of what it was, we (or I) devoured it.

We also got the endive salad and the flatbread. The flatbread had great flavor and the ingredients married perfectly; the only suggestion that I would make would be use a focaccia or actual pizza dough instead of the almost cracker like "flat bread". We also enjoyed the salad. 

The place was rather crowded and it took us around 45 minutes before we got a table. They really need to put some heat lamps outside and maybe a happy hour menu. All in all, I liked the atmosphere and the large wine/beer selection.
author: Alice W.

description:
Loved (almost) everything about Fat Angel besides the crazy wait. People tend to lounge around due to their awesome selection of wines, beers, cheese & meat platters. I was tempted to, but the long line piling up at the door made me feel bad. 

Chicken pot pie is a MUST. Their apple bread pudding was pretty great too. Despite the craziness, staff was super accomodating, patient, and knowledgeable.
author: Vivian D.

description:
***Warning the race card will be used***

So if you get all butt hurt about cultural honesty, perhaps you move it to the left...?

In July of 2010, I stumbled into this bar with 90 minutes to spare prior to series of spa treatment appointments at Kabuki. I went in for a glass of wine and peace of mind. The day was cray and I was the hottest of messes! I should also add that it was 3pm in the afternoon, July 1st and as a social worker I had spent the entire day in the TL...and I looked like I did too!
So I walk in, looking like a vagrant. I'm Black in a rapidly gentrifying area.  And I was already livid at the effort it took to get a cab to the area (As cabbies saw me, perhaps thinking I was a junkie, or money less scammer and would pass me by) So I'm thinking...there is no way I'm going to get great service, as...well....our White brothers and sisters see what the choose to see sometimes.....and often it lacks accuracy or the whole story...

However, I walked in with all the disheveled entitlement of a bag lady needing a drank...and got superb service from the chick bartender(who herself disclosed an interest psych/social welfare)...tried an amazing Red wine from Argentina, and had land meat for the first time in 4+ yrs when the Free range Sliders were explained as one of their choice dishes (my digestive track is still pissed about it however).
I started coming here monthly.
 I love this place....there can be some hipster attitude, but is usually minimum at best.
 
 I took my partner last night and we sit down to a meal and spend 90 bucks.....but totally worth it... The trout salad and fried polenta is to die for....I have spent hours here just trying the ales....
Keep up the great work Fat Angel...and thanx for always treating me well; Doo Rag, or 'Hair Did'!!
author: Ginger V.

description:
Really stoked about this fairly new joint.

Their flat bread is delicious - think of them as very very thin pizza!
Mac & Cheese - always good.
Chicken Pot Pie - soul warming.

So many types of interesting beer on tap? Sold!
author: Ami Y.

description:
The most quaint little gastropub!!  

Drinks:
-- Wines on tap!!!
-- Big selection of beers. Their selection of beers on tap change frequently.  
-- I ordered a Japanese expresso stout on tap!  Who would have thought that Japan would produce stouts?  And that it would be good?  And that a bar here would have it on tap?!
-- LOTS of other stouts available.  (Hey.... I'm really into stouts...)

Greatly enjoyed the food:
[[ Chicken Pot Pie ]]- a bowl of delicious filling, generous on the shredded chicken; topped with a thick piece of buttery, flakey, crust. The ratio of filling and crust was perfect for me
[[ Flatbread with mushroom & white truffle oil ]] - thin and crispy crust - fresh and light, not greasy
[[ Mac n' Cheese ]] - 3 different types of cheese, nice little crusty bits throughout.  

My only complaint would be that it gets way too crowded here, even early on a weekday.  Anybody want to join me for early mid-afternoon drinking?
author: Jeanne L.

description:
Came in on a Saturday night - they don't take reservations, so we just showed up around 8:00PM. About a 20 minute wait (during which time, drinks were involved). It's a small place, and I think we got lucky on the timing - our wait time really wasn't bad at all.

The drinks are priced anywhere from the regular/affordable and up to a 'sky is the limit' deal - pick what you want. The selections were nice, something for everyone - check out their menu for more to choose from, not just the board.

Very casual atmosphere, hip... all that good stuff - it is a small place, so we were almost elbow to elbow with the table next to us, not that it was a problem.

As food goes, we had the polenta fries (loved it), the maple bacon butter, some of the meat (I can't remember the name), a kale salad, and the mac and cheese - with a drink on the tab, we only came out to $50! If I was going to exclude anything, it would have been the meat - not that it was bad in any way, but the rest of the menu is what I'd suggest trying! It was simply the least memorable part of the meal. The salad in particular stood out for both of us - and an order of that is easily good for three people (we couldn't quite finish it with two of us). The mac & cheese was more on the order of 2 people, I think.

As someone mentioned, if it isn't too breezy that evening, consider bringing a jacket and sitting outside if you want to sit and eat quickly; that evening, I think only one group elected to sit outside, the rest of us waited for a spot inside!
author: Peter L.

description:
Okay so several visits later, have to update my review. Still give it 4 stars so long as it's a nice night/day out and you're outside. Otherwise, the inside is pretty much just like any other crowded, loud bar.  Upon walking in, it took 7 minutes for anyone to even acknowledge us or make eye contact.  Host walked past us about 4 times with his ipad.  

Took more standing right by the bar to get someone's attention who then said they needed to check with the host who again ignored us until we jumped in front of him as he walked by the 5th time.  Finally sit down, takes another couple of minutes for the waitress to get to us, though she was apologetic, which I can appreciate.  Our order came pretty quickly which was nice. But took us another 10 minutes to get our plates, napkins and knife.  As good as the cheese was, I still need a knife.  We had to ask multiple people to get our place settings.

Finally when we're all settled in, trying to enjoy our food and libations, table next to us was just filled with loud obnoxious guys who seemed to want to have all their friends join them at a small 4-person table.  Their waiter was as eager to participate in this "bumpin" night as they were.  Wondering if he was on something too since he bumped into and stepped on my foot a few times while trying to take their order.  No apologies.

We were very eager to leave.  If you find yourself here, do yourself a favor and stay outside.  2 stars for their indoor experience, and 4 for their outdoor experience.
author: Sandy K.

description:
This place is a real cool place to hang out.  Very nice vibe going on with the smallish space and the low lighting.  Nice date place.  The food looked really good, especially the bread pudding, wow.  

On this evening though Betty and I only had beer from the tap.  Very good selection.  I enjoyed the Hopoholic 4x IPA by Knee Deep Brewing Company.  Uh huh, 15.5%!  Obviously a sipper, but actually very easy drinking.  For dessert I had the Biere de Chocolat by Almanac Beer Co. :)  Very tasty as well.  We came with our friend Daniel who suggested coming here and we were glad we did.  Now if I could only get that bread pudding shipped to Tampa.
author: Bob B.

description:
So cute. So good. 

With amazing food,  sweet ambiance and a  killer bar, this place has it all. 

We tried a cheese plate, flatbread with wild mushroom, white truffle oil, and pecorino,   and a salad with endive, apple, candied walnuts, gorgonzola and cider vinaigrette. 

The salads are the size your face, so we could have just eaten that, but who wants to eat just salad when there are so many other tasty options?

I wish I had gotten around to trying a drink. That'll be for next time.
author: Amber K.

description: Pricey, small portions, good selection.  The thing that kicks it into four star territory is that everything I tried was top notch quality.  You won't get a lot of bang for your buck, but you will enjoy your meal.
author: Patrick R.

description:
I LOVE Fat Angel. 

The flatbreads are amazing ... try the Basil pesto, black olives, roasted tomatoes w/ ricotta & sausage. Yummmm

Even better? The chicken pot pie... best one I have ever had... EVER. 

Huge and delicious salad portions.... great to share. 

A great LITTLE spot... come early or you wil for sure have a wait. But service is always nice and they also have a few seats outside under heat lamps :)
author: Shannon H.

description: They have a fantastic selection of sour beers. Hoping to return for a proper meal someday...
author: Claudine C.

description: This place totally rocks! I half hope that less people know about it since the crowds can be a bit much to handle, but the food is wicked good, the drinks are just right and the atmosphere, when not too crowded, is very welcoming.
author: Tyler B.

description: BBJ like.  Huge selection of wines by the glass and bottled beers.  Supposed to have draft beer as well, but I didn't see it nor was it mentioned.  Food was good, prices fair, and good portions.  Friendly service as well.  The chicken pot pie was uniquely presented.
author: Big Baby Jesus C.

description: The Mac N cheese was so unreal that my date on the paleo diet ate half of it. And def ask for sausage in the Mac N cheese. The beer and wine selection is really extensive, too. Will be coming back.
author: Eric T.

description: Nobody actually likes kale, right?  But they would if they went to Fat Angel and ordered the kale salad with bacon, toasted almonds and vinagrette.  It was a massive bowl of leaves, but because it wasn't drenched in dressing, it was easy to enjoy the lot of it.  Restaurants rarely do vegetables or salads this well or with such a great serving size.  The restaurant was extremely crowded and the service wasn't perfet, but the buzz was delightful and the lighting was perfectly dim.  My daughter ordered the chicken pot pie and it was also about the tastiest one we've ever tried.  Too bad the hotel didn't have a fridge for the leftovers!  Too rich to eat the whole thing, but would have been great to share.  This place is a gem.
author: Sara S.

description:
Their salads are huge and their food is satisfying and creative, their beer list comprehensive. I love that they have wine on tap, though I sometimes wish they had a better wine-by-the-glass selection (well, I think the main issue is their selection is  just not really my taste, and I think they could do a good job of bringing in some small production stuff from the central coast, etc, that larger restaurants and bars can't carry due to production limits).

My main beef is just that it's always totally crowded and there is no clear system of organization to get a table, and you can't tell who works there and who doesn't. It's enjoyable if you can swing by on a day when you can instantly get a table and enjoy yourself with some friends.
author: Caroline C.

description: Amazing food, drink selection, ambiance, fairly priced, great date spot, loved it.
author: Kevin A.

description: Really a hidden gem.  If Fat Angel was located in SOMA or the Mission I'm sure there'd be a line out the door, but unusual spot of Fillmore mostly keeps the crowd to those in surrounding neighborhoods.  It's a great place to stop in for some cheese, sausage and fine Belgian beers.
author: John H.

description:
I really enjoyed the experience here. We ordered their Cinsault/Syrah/Cabernet blend and it was a table hit. I also enjoyed the Textbook Cabernet Sauvignon/Cabernet Franc. 

For chow we had the butters, mushroom flatbread and sliders. All of it was amazing. My favorite of the butters was definitely the garlic chili though.
author: Jennifer P.

description:
What a Fun neighborhood gastropub!

- Great service: everyone running the bar was friendly and fun despite the Craaaaazy Saturday crowd. Wonderful ambience too

- Very generous with their drinks

- Skip the Apple Bread Pudding- i'm sorry, but it was really disgusting; the worst dessert i'd eaten in a while. Texturally gummy and hard, flavor-wise- absolutely flavorless. It was like chewing a gummy flour ball swimming in a plate of whipped cream (or was it melted ice cream? i don't even know)

- My friend seemed to enjoy the mushroom flatbread, so i guess the food is not entirely bad. Just the bread pudding

HIghly recommend except for dessert (please do something about it! I really want to get a good dessert there!)
author: Jocelyn L.

description: I was treated very poorly compared to the other customers. The selection of wine and beer was vast. But the waiter and the bartender were very pushy and would roll their eyes at me when I ordered. I did not feel comfortable or welcome here and I will not be going back.
author: Josh F.

description: Great selection of wine and artisanal beers. The food did not disappoint either! The only downside is that the space is small and gets crowded.
author: Claudia R.

description:
Fat Angel is located right next to the busy Fillmore St., and is obverse to a small park. At nighttime, the whole park is lighten up by a blue LED light projected from the top of a marvelous building. The effect turns the park into a visionary scene from the movie Avatar. It's really quite beautiful.

The cute fat angel statue is hanging on the restaurant, smiling and waving to every incoming customer.

An interesting fact is that Fat Angel doesn't carry mainstream beers. My beer-drinker boyfriend had no idea what to order when there were strange beer brands from that stretched from England to the Netherlands and everywhere in-between. Finally, the owner recommended us to try an English bitter: Engels Brouwerij De Molen. The beer had a similar taste to my Alan's favorite beer, Blue Moon. Compared to Blue Moon, the body of Engels is a little bit lighter, but very smooth.

A lot of previous customers of Fat Angel recommended the Chicken PotPie on yelp. I decided to give it a try for this first time visit, which I found to be quite an interesting dish indeed.
For the chicken potpie, the owner recommended me to pair the pie with a white or red wine with a light body. I craved for the red wine on this beautiful night, so I went with the glass of red to soothe my cravings. In the end, I decided to go with what the owner had suggested, a Grenache from Santa Cruz, CA, Birichino 'Vieilles Vignes.'  My, was it wonderful.

Although the look of Fat Angel's chicken potpie was different from a traditional potpie, it still has the ability to fill up a gigantic stomach. My stomach was about to explode after I've barely finished a half of the potpie. All ladies have to be ready to ask their boyfriends to finish what is left from this gigantic dish! The powdery sauce was smooth, thick, pure, fresh and brisk. The Pot Pie and Grenache from Santa Cruz paired quite well with each other, but they where not perfect. I couldn't help but keep my mind stimulated by looking for another pairing to perfect this wine and potpie collaboration and  build a stronger relationship between the taste buds within my mouth.

I will definitely go back to Fat Angel to give a second look at their well-known cheese served w/ organic Firebrand Bread and seasonal accents.

Cheers!
author: Nobe Z.

description: Things started out a little rough on a chilly Friday night when we had to hang out outside for a while, waiting for a table. At first it seemed like a lost cause, as the waitstaff only came by to bus other tables and comment how refreshing it was outside compared to the stuffiness inside. It didn't feel so nice as we were waiting! Another employee came out, took our name, and we were seated without a terribly lengthy wait. However, given how small the place is, I would be reluctant to come back when it's busy. The beer selection is pretty great, and the snacks (which the menu focuses on) are better than the main courses. The fried capers were fantastic and the good-sized dish of them really went a long way, and the serving of the smoked trout salad was quite large and good for sharing. However, I found the chicken pot pie to be too tarragon-y and would not get that again.
author: Lisa K.

description:
Fat Angel is a good place to just lay back, relax, and drink some wine. The place has a rather romantic atmosphere, and would be a good place to bring a date. 

They have an amazing selection of beer and wine there, and the one I picked (Riesling) was nothing short of terrific. I had a good evening overall, and would come back to this place if I'm ever in the area.

The service was decent. The food and drinks here are a little pricey, however, but I would say it's reasonable given the nice atmosphere.
author: Don L.

description:
I've been on a 5-star roll. Thank you Yelpers for guiding me!

I was very impressed with this place. Our server was incredibly patient, knowledgeable and basically went above and beyond. We mentioned this was our first time at Fat Angel, and he thoughtfully walked us though the menus (Drink Menu - they have 38 bottles of wine available and some Belgian beers and non-alcoholic; Food Menu - includes various meats, cheeses, butters, a few comfort entrees - i.e. mac-n-cheese, chicken pot pie, and flatbreads - we had the asparagus + toasted pine nuts - excellent!). Our guy asked us questions on what type of wine we like and made great recommendations on pairing the wine + food. 

This place is cozy, so seating can be tight. Nice candlelit ambiance at night. They have bar seating + table seating. It's a great place to stop in and relax over quality beverage + food + service. Heaven indeed.
author: Cathy K.

description: Been here a few times, seems its going downhill a bit to be honest. They need to step up their game and not settle for the fact they're booked up every night. The two salads we ordered were below average, sent one back, had wilted lettuce. The anchovy pizza was good and the beer, of course is always good. Food overall very average for SF.
author: Ru B.

description: This place is one of my favorites.  Cute little bar and restaurant with outdoor seating. The menu is smaller, but the food is oh so delicious! There are little cheese plates which are super tasty and a variety of wines and beers to choose from. The sliders are amazing. The staff is very friendly. If it's too chilly, there is seating inside as well as the bar, but there are outdoor heaters which work pretty well; great for people watching. This place is a great date spot!
author: Char M.

description: Great wine bar with fantastic tapas style menu. There are a few main plates if you need something more substantial. I had the Chicken Pie which was delicious and a first rate Creme Brûlée.
author: Donna F.

description:
I was looking up places to check out after the Yelp event at Yoshis...and came across Fat Angel. I saw the positive reviews but what really caught my eye were the wines on draft...whoa? That sealed the deal.
We strolled up around 7ish on a Sunday..the place was still pretty quiet. The decor and setting is romantic and cozy...perfect for dates. I couldn't take my eyes off the stunning chandelier above the bar!

The bartenders were both friendly and tenacious.
We tried the sliders, the flat bread and some mortadella...
What I really wanted were the Mac-n-Cheese and Pot Pie..I guess that will have to wait til next time...and what we had were pretty good...

This wine bar has only been open for two weeks..and currently have two wines on draft..They also offer a solid list of unique and adventurous wines. 

Fat Angel is definitely a welcome addition to the neighborhood and I look forward to coming back!
author: Mimi T.

description:
When I think of angels, I think of Charlie and his bevy of beauties, or those svelte VS models in their underwear and stilettos (because thats is EXACTLY what women do at home boys..we like to do housework in matching lingerie and 4 inch heels..pfsh).

Anyhoo...
When I think of fat angels I think of cherubic funny little butterballs with wings and trouble on their minds or me after I have eaten a donut.

So imagine my amusement when I saw in the pouring rain, the way to Fat Angel because of the shiny golden angel they have floating above their entrance.
It is SO like a sign from the heavens right?!?

WELL....this place is an utter and absolute gem.
It is smaller than what I thought, but it made for a really cozy, intimate atmosphere which is perfect for a girls night out, a romantic date or a nice glass of wine by yourself at the bar after a long day.
The gorgeous chandelier is brilliant in its sparkly goodness (yay sparkles!) and the decor is rustic old man cigar  room charm.

I ordered a nice glass of viognier and enjoyed some cheese and salami appetizers and then had the sliders.

                                        OMG.

The sliders? What can I say? They were pure, unadulterated deliciousness on a lightly buttered bun with this amazing garlic aioli that had me licking my fingers  and moaning with pleasure like some sort of porn star. A--mazing.
I don't know how the mac and cheese or the pot pie taste, but if they are half as good as the sliders, I'm going to have to watch it before I make a one woman spectacle of myself in the corner.

The service was great and friendly. They were busy so it was a little bit of time before I got my order in, but it was also a small staff serving a bunch of people and I was in absolutely no rush. But the bartender and the servers were super friendly and down to earth.

I am excited to have this great place in the neighborhood as the Fillmore needs some more down to earth and classy establishments (without the hype of a place like Yoshis).  It adds a nice member to my repertoire of places to go out and I highly recommend it. 
*Unless of course you take up a seat when I want to go there in which case move it buddy or else a fat angel is going to be coming for you.*
author: Kathy K.

description:
Who you calling fat?

Exotic, rare beers on tap.

Capers in their take on the Caeser salad MMM.

Usually busy, but tables turn fast. They won't disappoint.
author: Scott G.

description: I've been back to Fat Angel a couple of times after that fateful missed connection, and they always deliver a great time - tasty bites, nice atmosphere, and a GREAT beer selection.  If you haven't been here, I don't know why not.  It's a great first date spot too!
author: Jennifer D.

description:
I am generously giving Fat Angel one star. I say generously because it probably deserves like a half a star...if that. I moved into the building upstairs from the restaurant  about eight months ago and was so excited to have a place so (seemingly cute) and close. My boyfriend and I go out A LOT, so it would have been really nice. 

Upon entering Fat Angel, I was pushed aside by an incredibly rude server? host? No idea since he said not a word to me except to gasp that I dare try to get through the door while he juggled his, um, 3 tables outside. Life is so hard. 

I finally found my way through and waited for ANYONE to say hello to me. After about ten minutes I said something to the incredibly rude woman behind the bar. Oh, how dare I think I was getting a seat. Hilarious. I was allowed to stand in the two-foot by two-foot space right next to the door while I sipped my wine. It should be noted that the wine and beer selection are excellent so if you care nothing about your dignity and only your boîte, this is the place for you.
 
The night went on like that, laughably. At the end, after, drinking a few bottles and enjoying the cheese plate, we waited and waited and waited for the bill. After being done for about 25 minutes, I went up to the bar and asked for the bill--I was honestly embarrassed for them and they were not at all fussed. 

"Here." (Apparently my money is no good here.)  

Okayyyyy.

I vowed never to go there again. Plus I told EVERYONE how mush it sucked. Then one night my boyfriend said: "Hey, my friend from college is pretty much best friends with the owner." 

Oh crap. 

So I tried again. 

Same horrible service. Same horrible attitudes. I cannot believe this place is in business and it baffles me that there are people who are genuine regulars here. 

I went back one night, tipsy, and ordered a glass of wine and told the bartender it was seriously the last chance. After that, they have been sweet as can be to me. But, it makes me feel dirty so I don't ever sink that low anymore.

My point is--good luck to you. If they happen to be nice to you or, gasp, actually give you good service, you are among the lucky few.
author: Samantha H.

description:
Word of the Meal: CRAMPED

So the Mister and I, being from Los Angeles, are becoming more conscious about our caloric intake, health and fitness. In addition to regular exercise and healthy eating, we recently cut out processed carbs and unnecessary sugars after 6pm. One day, I just couldn't take it anymore. So, we went to Fat Angel since it was two blocks away. It was packed on a cold, dreary night. Nobody appeared to be hosting or seating people, so I made my way to an empty table and sat down. Not knowing if this was acceptable behavior at Fat Angel, I kind of went with it and went to town with the carbs. LOL.

We had the Pimm's cup and the Champagne cocktail for drinks. Neither of which were to die for. We then ordered the mac-n-cheese, chicken pot pie and sliders. The sliders had a good cook on them and were tasty. The chicken pot pie was yummy, but there wasn't enough crust and therefore, too much filling. The filling, however, did have a good amount of shredded chicken which I was glad they didn't skimp on. The mac-n-cheese was okay. It was served in a hot skillet which made scooping and serving the dish a bit difficult (there was no pan holder or hot glove to help in handling it). The Mister didn't take to the mac-n-cheese and said he could have made it himself. Although a fair assessment as far as difficulty of the dish, the Mister rarely cooks...yeah, go figure! Kettle meet pot. 

The service at Fat Angel was good, but the envirnoment was too cramped for our style. Other table's conversations were bleeding into ours, coercing silence. I did get what I was in search of - a few mouth fulls of starchy carbs, but I do not think I would go back again. A gastropub probably isn't my cup of tea, but I am sure others had a wonderful time at this neighborhood joint.
author: Sean A.

description:
This is a sweet little wine bar just off Fillmore street and perfectly situated for having a drink before or after a show at The Fillmore or a movie at the Kabuki!  (Or a movie at The Clay, which is where I was headed.)

I arrived at 6PM on a Friday by myself and got the last table.  They had a nice Happy Hour for "draft" wine & beer, but I decided against the house wine and went for the Sangiovese 2006 Savignola Paolina, Chianti Classico IT ($10).  I *did* decide to order a little appetizer off the Happy Hour menu.  I ordered the duck salami that came with a grainy mustard and bread in a bag (see my picture).  The presentation was beautiful and the service was friendly.

Another thing I really liked was how they presented their wine list.  I'm not a wine expert, but I know what I like and what I feel like drinking.  The wine I had was listed under "Bright and Juicy" and that's exactly what I wanted and wasn't disappointed.

This is a nice addition to the area!
author: Kimberly B.

description:
This place definitely has hit something with a fun atmosphere--almost feels like when the Spotted Pig first opened up in New York. They do really cool stuff with their butters (normally I would never order butter, but you have to do it here!), especially the maple bacon butter which is a "must try." 

The cheeses and cured meats are great as well, and you can do mac and cheese and flatbread while you're at it.

Also don't forget this is a wine bar, but they do a great job with small food items.

The only improvement would be if it was on Fillmore itself instead of on a side street, but you can't have everything.
author: Mike G.

description:
Mixed feelings. When I arrived I was told to wait in the front for my friends to be seated which is not surprising. However most tables were empty but the standing area was so packed that it was difficult to cross the room on my way back to the front. It was obvious that the 25 people standing around were part of a group that came for drinks and did not want to sit down. So instead of making my way to the front I sat down at one of the 10 free tables. This place is so small with only 12 tables. The waitres which were not paying that much attention through the whole evening came over immediately to remind me to wait in the front.

Service: food came at different times, wine arrived after the food although ordered a long time before. Waited for the check quite long too. Waiters forgot orders.

Food: the small smoked trout salad had way less trout compared to our neighbor's plate. The 3 cheese selection was quite expensive for what it was. Portion was good but $$. The taste of everything was good.
author: Chris S.

description:
I bet it's every guy's dream to open up a restaurant so he could feed his nuts to dozens of beautiful, drunk women nightly. I'm not ashamed to say...I had Cy's Salty Sweet Chinese Nuts ($4) & loved them. You know I've been sitting on that intro for a few days! *wink* 

Other edibles:
-- fried capers, $3: not what I expected. Crispy, salty but needed a lil' sumfin, sumfin to be eaten with. 
-- charcuterie platter, $23 for 5: not sure what meats he chose but I tried a salami w/ black pepper which had an understated taste, nothing wild or spicy about it
-- maple bacon butter & bread, $4.5: I should have gone for the garlic chili...
-- FA's chicken pot pie, $12: one of my least favorite pot pies, sadly. Sherry, tarragon, carrots & roasted chicken had the consistency of goopey mush. There was a spice that totally turned me off (cumin? coriander? curry?) The pastry top had many flakey layers. 
-- mac & cheese, $11: loved the corkscrew pasta & the generous crunchy topping. Cheese wasn't as sharp as I would've liked & too runny. 

More misses than hits, so three stars for our dinner is more than generous. Service was impeccable; Jason & Cy are amazing hosts & their establishment is beautiful & archetypal San Francisco. I just don't think their food style matches what I'm looking for. Give their extensive alkie list a gander; you're guaranteed to find a very sipable libation.
author: Fancypants X.

description:
I LOVE GASTROPUBS! There's something about darkened and packed restaurants with cozy yet humbling food that really strikes a chord with me... I think Fat Angel might have been my first SF gastropub foray. I wasn't disappointed!

I came here for pre-show dining before seeing Shabazz Palaces at Yoshi's SF. If you're going to Yoshi's for music, I highly recommend you come here instead of dining at Yoshi's; Yoshi's is overpriced and doesn't taste very good. Fat Angel was only a couple blocks away from the venue.

The wait is a little long, and since the establishment is pretty small, I had to wait outside. There is some bar seating, but I opted for the tables instead. The atmosphere was sexy yet understated, and the noise level was at a comfortable middle between awkward low and overbearing high.

What we had:

Maple bacon butter: As a self-proclaimed butter aficionado, I approve this dish! It reminded me of a buttery reincarnation of Frances' Bacon Beignets. When I ran out of bread, I started eating the butter on its own; NO REGRETS.

Mac n' cheese: I'm not a huge fan of mac n cheese, but since my boyfriend seems to be stuck in fourth grade, we gave it a try. It was AMAZING! They used conchiglie rigate (or what I always refer to affectionately as the "shell pasta", and the dish was served on a cast iron mini-casserole. Yum!

Chicken pot pie: Not as great as the mac n cheese, I'm afraid, but memorable in its own right. If you have never broke the shell on a steaming hot pie with the back of your spoon, you are missing out.

I'll be back for you, Fat Angel.
author: Hanui C.

description: Great barkeep attitude and beer selection
author: Kevin F.

description:
A wine bar with an entire section of the menu devoted to butter?  I'd almost think it strange if this joint weren't sandwiched between two jazz clubs that serve traditional Ethiopian food.  Gotta love a wine bar that offers more snacks than just cheese (not that there is anything wrong with that).  Wine on draft was kind of cool too, though wish they'd offer it in a proper pint...

Fried Capers w/ Sage: I thought fried pickles were cool, but they don't hold a spear to fried capers!  Seemed like caper flavored air-filled raisins.  Each wrinkly skin of caper shatters in your mouth leaving just a wisp of bitter caper taste and a lot of salt.  Great on the innovation front, but felt a little grease overload halfway through.  Best to share.

Maple Bacon Butter: Why did it take so long for someone to offer this?  Two of my favorite things together at once.  Real bits of fresh crisp bacon in a mound of extra buttery butter.  The bread offered was nice, but mainly just a vehicle for me to enjoy this butter because spooning it directly into my mouth would be a huge social faux pas.

Wild Mushroom & Truffle Oil w/ Pecorino Flat Bread: The bread was extremely thin, like a cracker.  Kind of reminded me of a makeshift pizza I once made from leftover whole wheat lavash bread.  The truffle oil wasn't heavily pronounced, they need to use more.  Overall, not so much a fan.

Mac-daddy Mac n' Cheese w/ Bacon: Dense spirals that manage to stick some gooeyness between each ramp.  The dense chewy texture was a nice change of pace compared to the limper elbows often offered.  The bacon was a nice add-in as always, but could have been crispier.

Blueberry Tart: Not on the menu, but a substitute for the dessert they ran out of.  It was more like a mini blueberry cobbler than a tart.  Loved how the freshly whipped cream melted ever so subtly over it's luke warm dough.  Had that great jam-like blueberry texture which feels richer than the flowing berries of a traditional blueberry pie.
author: Adam B.

description:
This nice and cozy gastropub located just a stone throw away from Japantown offers great wines, beers and eats.

The eclectic mix of various new and old world wines is certainly more than adequate for a night of drinks and food. It probably wouldn't get noticed by WineSpectator, but the selection should be satisfactory to all but the most snobbish wine drinkers. The beer list is several pages long and quite a few are on tap as well. I'm more of a wine drinker than a beer drinker myself. But since this place is clearly known for the beers they serve, I just told the bartender that I liked hefeweizens and just give me whatever they have on tap that was closest to it. I don't remember the name of the beer I got, but I was happy with it.

From the kitchen I ordered the Basil pesto, black olives, roasted tomatoes & sausage w/ ricotta flat-bread. The bread itself was paper thin and crunchy yet still strong enough to support the tasty toppings. My only complaint is that I think sausage is a bit overpowering flavorwise. It still went well with my beer.

The waitress suggested I try the mac n' cheese which I ordered as well. She warned me that it was very hot. I dismissed her warning thinking she probably has to say that to everyone because she has to deal with a lot of people who are not used to eating spicy food. When the mac n' cheese arrived, I was a bit surprised because it was hot! Not so spicy that it was inedible, but spicy enough that you really wanted that beer to take the burn away.

Only two bartenders were holding down the fort all night and I must say that they did an excellent job of making sure everything was ok and getting all the drinks out.

This place is super popular with the locals. Either get here early or expect to wait.
author: Glen L.

description:
8:00: (entering the bar) "I love chandeliers! I love deer! I love organ pipes!!

8:05: (waiting for seat at the bar) "I love champagne in a half glass! 

8:06: "I did not know that I also love champagne cocktails with bitters in a half glass--so glad that was cleared up. 

8:30: (Seated) I love Cabernet Franc/Merlot/Cab. Sauv. blends!! I love wine by the glass!!! 

8:40: "Homemade butter?!?! Are you kidding me? I love butter!!!  

(lots of eating and drinking and laughing.)

10:00 (after all of the butter, cheese, and wine is gone) "I love life. I love life too, too much."
author: Lynn M.

description:
Mac & cheese: 4 stars. I've had a lot of Mac & cheese and this by far was in the top 5.
Basil marinara & arugula w/ ricotta flatbread: 2 stars. Eh, not much flavor and wasn't impressed with the flatbread.
Chicken pot pie: 3 stars. Pretty flavorful and rich.
Bread pudding: 3 stars.  The whipped cream was amazing but the bread pudding itself was not very good. I couldn't get any sense of bread in the pudding.
Ambience: sophisticated but also laid back
Service: 4 stars. Very attentive but not too attentive that it's overwhelming!
I will absolutely come back for the Mac & cheese..
author: Monica A.

description:
5 stars for ambiance 

Soooo cozy and nice on the inside! But too busy to seat our group of 6 indoors, so we sat outside. 

5 stars for service. 

The waitstaff was super friendly!

4 stars for food

Mac and cheese is okay, but certainly not the best this connoisseur has ever had. Sliders were amazeballs. Pot pie excellent, with strong notes of tarragon. Flatbreads pretty good with intense flavors.
author: Maddie G.

description:
Always very busy. The food and drinks menu is very good. Although I do think this place is slightly overhyped.

Food Quality - Excellent.
Food Taste - Good.
Food Originality - Excellent.
Price - Good.
Customer Service - Good.
Ambiance - Good.
author: Vibhor C.

description:
ivy.yelp.com and I used to frequent this place weekly. Dark casual gastropub vibe. Great salads the size of a human head. Pot pie = extraordinary. A real charcuterie plate. And a really eclectic and inventive beer menu that stood out in a town where Racer 5 has turned into the local equivalent of Miller Lite as far as distribution. And best of all, few crowds and attentive service.

Then came this evening (a Tuesday, no less), as I walked into the restaurant. To myself: "Whoa, is that guy wearing dark-rimmed glasses? What are we, on Valencia?" "Hold on, is this a line on a Tuesday night for a table?" And then, "Oh no, I'm sensing a lot of plaid and male skinny jeans in this room." Then I realized that I walked by a few bikes on the way in. Oh. No.

That's right. This place has been uncovered by hipsters. For that, I would love to give this place zero stars, but I just can't. Despite the fact that service was unusually slow (trying hard not to blame the huge influx of hipsters), everything else was great as usual.

Just remember when a hipster tells you that they "found" an amazing new place on the fringe of Western Addition: random yuppie asian people were there first.
author: Jack C.

description:
This place is consistently very good.  I've only been on "off hours" (weeknight or weekend afternoon), but I'd characterize Fat Angel as a quaint little gastropub with solid food and a nice selection of beers and wine.  This is a good place to go if you want to be able to actually be able to actually talk to your companion.  I've had the cheese plate and flatbreads.  Would recommend both.  

The service has been good and attentive though I've been at the bar both times.  Looks to me like they typically only have a couple of folks working the front of the house, but it's a small place so I think it works.  

It's worth a shot...especially if you live in the neighborhood.  Never have left anything but satisfied.
author: Michael B.

description:
This is my go-to wine place in my neighborhood.  Great wine, reasonable prices, without the much despised pretentiousness.

I always order the Grenache blend, which is delicious.  I love the flatbreads too.  The service is kind and attentive.  

Check it out if you're in the neighborhood!
author: Jade F.

description:
We were excited to eat and drink here, but never had the opportunity to do either. We got there around 7:30 on Thursday night and it was pretty busy but no one waiting to be seated. We asked how long the wait was and she told us 40-45 minutes (there isn't a lot of seating), so we asked her to put us on the list. She took our phone number and said she'd call/text when a table became available. There wasn't anywhere to stand and wait, so we took a walk until we got a call, but we never heard back from her. Not sure if we would have eventually been seated had we waited around or if it's a good thing that we went elsewhere while we could, but this was a big let down since we were all looking forward to checking this place out.

Lesson learned: it's a pretty small restaurant so expect long waits or make reservations (if they take them).
author: Ryan G.

description:
from two visits....
Great drink options, including wines and lots of unusual beers.
Interesting, tasty bar food options, but small portions for the price.
Friendly and knowledgeable bar staff.
It is tiny and cozy inside, so you may have to wait.  There is outdoor seating, but it can be chilly.  Bring a lap blanket and you are good!
author: Monica S.

description:
I usually don't write reviews, however our experience at this restaurant was quite horrible to the point where I felt there was a need to share.

This was our second visit to Fat Angel. We came here on around 10:30 and were seated after a couple of mins since we were also getting dinner. The place looked quite unorganized, the bartender was also the server and there were only another female server for a crowded place. 

We sat down and ordered our drinks. The drinks came momentarily, after we told them we were ready to order. He got our order in, there were a couple of other tables behind us who ordered later. We waited for almost 20mins for our cold cut plate. I don't know how long it takes to slice meat. But as I looked up, the tables who ordered way later already received their cold cut plates and salads! When my bf tried to speak to the waiters, they ignored him. I managed to catch the attention of the female waitress and explained to her that everyone else who ordered after us had received their food, even the hot plates yet we only had drinks. 

After 5-10 mins, our food began to come. The male server who was also the bartender made no attempt to explain or apologize for the significant delay, and acted as if nothing had happened. When we ordered dessert, they made no attempt to clear our table full of plates, instead piled the dessert plate on our stacked table. We had to essentially gather our own plates to have them being taken away. 

As for the food, the cold cut platter was standard. The chicken pot pie was quite good, but the salad was overly dressed and soggy since it probably had been sitting on the counter for a long time. The creme brulee was average. After this experience, the poor management and avg. food, it is safe to say we will not be recommending this restaurant to anyone or coming anymore.
author: Vanessa C.

description: A nice place to grab a glass. Cozy and unexpected. No zins, though. My group wished they would serve food later.
author: Andrew K.

description:
The bf and I have tried to get into Fat Angel since we moved across the street, but it's always slammed. You can only imagine how excited we were when we were able to grab seats at the bar the other day. What joy! Great service, semi small menu, but full  of great dishes and reasonable prices.

Bonus - large beer/wine list with a few fun cocktails

Food/Drink highlights...meaning, GET THESE! 
*Pimm's Cup...light, refreshing, delicious!
*Lemon/sage/caper butter,
* Cheese plate (favorites were Vella Dry Jack  NorCal hard cow,  Wisconsin semi-soft cow and El Trigal  Spanish semi-firm sheep)
*Organic Firebrand bread (comes with cheese and butter)
*Sliders (beef, caramelized onions, bacon, irish cheddar, aioli) - no words can express how tasty these are. 

Note - this place is pretty small...so either head there early or expect to wait. 

Overall...do yourself a favor and give them a try. Soon!
author: Dru M.

description: Good selection of beer and wine although a tad pricey on the bottle selection.  I was able to try Lost Abbey's tequila barrel aged "Agave Maria" and it was great with their cayenne Mac & Cheese.  The lemon caper butter and bread was a good compliment for the beers and their wild mushroom truffle flatbread definitely makes me want to drive back here from the South Bay.  I will be back!
author: R K.

description: Came here with my hub on a Friday night around 5pm. Easily beat the rush! We opted to sit at the bar and have a couple beers rather than sit on the sidewalk patio.  We split the spicy Mac and cheese ( which didn't disappoint). Great beer list! Definitely got crowded around 6:30 though so get there early!
author: Kelly L.

description: Ri-god-dam-diculous
author: Mike J.

description:
Service is generally poor, but the other night we were completely ignored when we popped in for a glass of wine from the cold.  

Redeeming qualities include: the butter.  Yes, order the butter - sounds crazy - but it is delicious, do not order 2 - becuase you might hate yourself.
author: Jenn D.

description: This place has awesome food and awesome beers, however the short man with pig tails is very unaccommodating and has terrible customer service skills he refused to sit me and my girlfriend at a "table for 3 or more" as the place was emptying out. Look out for short pig tails man, otherwise this place is 5 stars.
author: Larry B.

description:
Four of us stopped by Sunday evening for a few adult libations and some snacks. We were promptly seated, drink ordered taken and before we knew it, drinks were served -:) 

We ordered the cheese tray, sliders and some of the garlic  jalapeño butter. I felt is was a bit odd to get butter but it turned out to be really really good.  

Everyone had a great time and we look forward to our next visit.
author: Wesley S.

description: Excellent beers on tap. You'll never see the same one twice. But you'll love every one you order.
author: Marc G.

description:
Securing a date with a pretty girl is easy for most guy, but I am not most guys and once again I disappointed my elitist friends and showed up stag for a company event. I figured it was the first Friday of March and I would be cut a little slack.

Maybe a better use of my time on Yelp is searching for a quality for a plastic surgeon rather than wine bars? I digress...

Fat Angel however did not disappoint. A galaxy of wines offered by the glass from all corners of the universe. The servers are experts at guiding you to that perfect copa of rioja and telling you it's story. Yes, you heard me right. Each glass of wine tells a tale. There is a famous line from Sideways describing the delicacy of the pinot noir grape. I can't exactly recite it verbatim, just take my word for it that it applies to this review

The last thing I need last night was another glass of alcohol especially after already consuming two martinis and your coworkers are riding you once again for failing on scoring a date. But I must say, through all the fuzziness of last night, Fat Angel delivered and was made an excellent end to a nice evening out with friends and all their *sigh* significant others.
author: V B.

description:
This place has horrible food and service. They have a limited menu and can not master the items on it! The staff took forever and were rude (always pointing at the costumers). If you are into the local brews, this place offers an interesting variety. Not being from the area, we asked both the bar tender and the waitress about the beers and they had no type of description that would be helpful. 

Overall, I would not recommend this place to anyone.
author: Morgan K.

description:
Cozy neighborhood feeling, delicious food (we had flat breads & bread pudding), amazing choices of drinks ( if you're into sour beer this is heaven) (or wine), friendly bartender/waiter, good decoration, lighting, music (different music in the restroom, it was playing nirvana when i pee :) maybe a little too cozy with tables too close to each other... Hard to move between tables. 
Overall it's definitely a great spot to grab a drink after work & a casual dinner! Highly recommended!
author: melissa n.

description: After nearly a fistful of years of coming here, I've learned to not attempt to fly in the face of the flapping wings of the high volume nights of Fat Angel. Instead, times like Sunday at 7 or Tuesday at 6 are times that match the relaxation of ordering butter, bread and wine. In the way the inside decor gives you a reprieve from the city design disaster that is the Fillmore Center, bread, butter and wine should come in a relaxed environment, not when you're fighting for tables. We accomplished a feat that seems as likely as not asking the server to take a photo immediately because of it: 10 of us gathered tables and enough chairs outside to all sit here. I'm not into the S&M of SF's competitive seating scene, but I am way into a GSM with garlic chili butter on a calm night in a special place like Fat Angel.
author: Jon A.

description:
The food was good so no complaints there but I don't think I ever want to go through the wait for a table here again. 

I think I would love Fat Angel more if it was less stressful to get a seat but you can't put in a reservation so you end up just wasting an hour of your life hoping to get seated. There's also no convenient place to wait unless you want to try outside under the heat lamps or if a bar space opens up.

No offense but as nice as Fat Angel is, nothing could tempt me to wait to be seated there again.
author: Rachel R.

description:
One of my favorite places in the City. Great environment, focused and executed menu and perfect mix of beer and wine. 

Would be 5 stars if service was more attentive and consistent but it's certainly not bad at all.
author: Matthew T.

description:
Dark and cozy gastropub in the Fillmore Jazz District. 

We had an interesting Mint chocolate stout and two other beers I can't remember. Their list is impressive (even a bit intimidating!) so I'd imagine beer/spirits lovers would have a blast! Given that range, there is also a $-$$$, so watch out. 

Fat Angel's pot pie came out piping hot--perfect for the two of us to share (especially since we'd just shared a platter of meats). Not too salty (which is often a boon to pot pies) and not too heavy. :) I'm a fan. 

We weren't shy about grilling the waitress (out of our ignorance) about the meat options for the chatrucerie board of meats. Do you know what this means?

I actually don't remember what they were anymore, but we went with the Duck Mousse, Hot Copa (pork butt), and one of them that was wild boar..because...boar is awesome!  The meats came out in layered rows, served up with Firebrand sourdough baguette slices and whole grain mustard on a wooden board. 

Go, Go, Go!
author: Vivian C.

description:
This place is my go to beer bar in the city.  It's a bit of a trip for me but it's always worth it.  They have it all-- great beer selection, awesome wine, fantastic food, and knowledgeable staff that will humor all of your stupid questions.  
My favs are the kale salad, red grape flatbread, and a refreshing sour beer.
author: Laura B.

description:
Let me start by saying that Fat Angel has great food, beer, and a very friendly staff--if you ever have a chance to meet them.  They seem to be overwhelmed by the popularity of their place and are understaffed to deal with the scads of people trying to patronize the place.  Good luck trying to find a seat and getting served.

Oh yeah, the beer selection is exceptional, though we could only get served one drink in the time given.  We both had flat breads (I had duck sausage, Luann had a lemon butter) and though I ordered a mac' n cheese they delivered a chicken pot pie my wife ordered the sliders.  The food was all comp'd because they got the order wrong, but admittedly it was delicious.  If not for the service, I'd probably give them 4 stars.  They have a good idea, they just need to figure out execution part.
author: Ed H.

description:
This place has declined precipitously. I have been going here shortly after it had opened and loved the selection of beer (amazing menu + tap rotation) and food (bougie bar food). 

HOWEVER, of late I have had 3 terrible experiences in a row. Why:

1) The service is atrocious. There are routinely too few waiters and bartenders. They always seem generally annoyed to serve you. 
2) The beer selection is diminished - as a bar this is bad. If you have 3 double IPAs and no belgian beers on tap, you're doing it wrong. 
3) They do not appreciate repeat business. I have met the same bartender probably five times, often going with my friend who lives across the street. Not once have we gotten a free drink or even just some better service. That's amateur hour compared to most other places I try to frequent.
author: Louis A.

description:
This is a really nice little bistro.
The staff are really nice, and the ambiance is great. 
This is a small plate restaurant, so if your starving I don't recommend you dine here.
It's also a little pricey, but there prices are justified based on there location and quality of food.
author: Khaled A.

description: Awesome beers here and their food is great too. Cozy atmosphere, we came at 6 and there were seats but by 7 it started getting crowded.
author: Dang L.

description: Okay so let me say this place is totally cute, the food is good... We were in SF for work and came here on a recommendation from a local.... We were quoted a 30-45 min waited  3.5 hours!   The wait would have been okay if we would have been allowed to sit at the "bar" and order more than olives and nuts but we were told that the bar seating was like a table and we couldn't sit and order... Okay... 3.5 hours later and table turnover on 2 tops that could have been pushed together but were not... A little annoying.  Biggest complaint is lack of foresight by the staff.  The host on duty was relying on 1 table to turnover for 3.5 hours!!!! Have a contingency plan.  By the time we got seated 3.5 hours later after a 30-45 min quote we were all a little frustrated at the lack of leadership.
author: Dianna M.

description:
Tucked away on what seems to be a side street is my new favorite wine bar - Fat Angel. I always have to remember it's angel, not angle. 

This little wine bar is so tiny but packs a lot of charm and character. From the dead deer head thingy on the wall, to the corks on the mantle, to the cute little delicate menus to their amazing selection of beers and draft wine, I may have found my new favorite wine bar.

I had their pinot noir on draft ($10/glass, $20/half bottle) and it was so delicious. Fruity and light just the way I am. Or the way I like it.

Their cheeses are really good and I really wanted to try their famous mac and cheese but that will just give me an excuse to come back and try possibly everything on their menu.

We got there yesterday night at 8:30 and the place was packed. We were lucky to find 2 seats at the bar. Definitely go early and if no seats are available, they have heat lamps outside for you to wait while tables open up.

Definitely one of my new favorite bars in the city. I love you!
author: Vanessa W.

description:
Perfect spot to hit before you head to a movie at the Kabuki theatre.  I'd give it five stars if they could mitigate the noise.  When it's crowded...it's hard to hear someone across the table.

They have a great green solution to wine bottles....they keep a cask and bring carafes to your table.  

Until this bar...I never explored the neighborhood behind the Fillmore.  It's a great anchor for the neighborhood.
author: Steven R.

description:
I really like the ambiance here. It's small and cozy, but hip and modern. The wine list is superb, the bartender (and only person working the front on a Monday night) was friendly and knowledgeable. 

We tried the special zucchini flatbread and the mushroom flatbread. Both were exquisite. Healthy pizza on a cracker. 

Also worth mentioning - the softest toilet paper I've ever experienced in a public place! And I usually don't care about such things.

My only complaint was that it was a bit pricey. My friend and I had two flatbreads and two glasses of wine each - we shared a third - and we spent about $60. If you stick to the Happy Hour menu, you could lower that considerably.
author: Kim C.

description: Perfect ambiance. Music, lighting, decor---all lovely. It is an intimate space, and they don't take reservations, so plan accordingly.  I had a 3 for $14 cheese and meat board. This also comes with bread, quince, figs, mustard, and assorted nuts. Very nice presentation. They also appear to have a fine selection of wine and beer. Romantic and cool, I love this little place.
author: Caddy M.

description: This place is absolutely adorable! It's very small and charming but has an amazing selection of beers and wine. The flatbread pizza was definitely my favorite thing off the menu!
author: Linda T.

description:
My bf and I often pass by this place on our way to quickly's but we never went in because it looked pricey. Tonight we were looking to splurge! 

Pros:
1) good portions for the price. 
2) Really tasty and refreshing lemonade. 

Cons:
1) Inattentive server who gave us attitude when we asked to order drinks while we waited for a table. 
2) The restaurant was small and cramped. They put too many seats at the bar so there was very little arm space. 
3) There was no ambiance because it was too loud to have a conversation without yelling.
4) I ordered the some salami, hot coppa, and speck. They tasted like grocery store salami. If you want good charcuterie, I recommend adesso in Oakland and boccalone at the ferry building.
5) my bf ordered the chicken potpie. He said that it was bland and that Marie calendars frozen potpie tastes better. 

Nothing really stood out here so I wasn't impressed.
author: Le T.

description:
Is it possible to be in love with a restaurant? I don't even know where to begin, my experience was so good. The ambiance of the place, small, and inviting with candles on each table, reminded me of a tavern I would go to in New England. Our server was friendly without being over bearing, and gave us plenty of time to decide what to order.
I had the chicken pot pie with tarragon and a glass of pinot grigio (full size!), and my friend had the mac and cheese with a glass of cab, and throughout dinner the two of us could not decide whose food was more amazing, it was that freaking delicious! 
Best of all, the wine and the food were not the normal crazy expensive San Francisco prices. 
Looks like I found my new favorite place to eat in San Fran. Can't wait to try the cheese plates next time.
author: Sarah W.

description:
Met friends for before dinner drinks on Saturday night :-) 

Pros -Lovely place, nice decor, indoor, outdoor seating, great ambiance ! 
          -The bartenders were friendly! 
          -Lots of beer and wine selection. 

I was sick and not drinking, but guess what? They had tea options......I was very happy with the Oolong (Goat's milk) tea recommended by the bartender. There wasn't goat's milk in it. It was Oolong...Not sure why it was called Goat's Milk! It was great! 


Cons - It was a little hard to find. 
           - It can get really loud!
author: Neelam M.

description:
I have heard about this place from friends so I decided to check it out. I had the slider mini burgers. Hands down the best sliders I've ever tasted. I suggest if you go, this is a must-try item. I also got to try the homemade chicken pot pie and the mushroom flat bread. Needless to say, my tastebuds were pleased!
I'm not a big fan of wine so the owner helped me pair my meal with a glass. They are down-to-earth, friendly and patient people. Did I mention very knowledgeable about their food and wines?
Here is my rating broken down:
1st star- excellent customer service
2nd star- place is kept clean and very nicely decorated
3rd star- seated promptly & wait time for food was fast
4th star- GREAT FOOD!!
5th star- unique. easy parking. definitely coming back!
author: Teresa C.

description:
9 of us walked-in to the Fat Angel Sunday night at 5pm. The staff let us know we were welcome and that they could accommodate our group - a respectful group who in 90- minutes was headed to Yoshi's for a 7 o'clock comedy show.
All orders were placed with the wait staff within five minutes of one another. During the next 90 minutes, half of our party was served and had finished eating two highly explosively spiced mac and cheeses, with no menu warning) the other three Mac and cheese dinners showed up equally explosive an hour later, when it was past time to be leaving for Yoshi's.
Salads arrived to no one in particular- that was left for us to sort out. Among the original order we placed  five plates of sliders. Four arrived during the last15 minutes and the "no onions" order arrived with five minutes to spare.

In courteous frustration, mid meal time, I did speak up to wait staff to explain that our aim of dining out together was missing the mark, as five of us were finished, and four had not yet seen any plates of food at all. 

A gentleman arrived, and addressed our table and apologized for our missed meals due to the fact that they were working with just one chef. It occurred to us all simultaneously that warning us of lack of cooks when we walked in the door would had honored our time, money, and the joy of sharing food with friends and family - something The Fat Angel Staff staff does not consider of value.

For our trouble, they comped one drink and one order of sliders which I passed around the table - time being what it was. TFC hardly made a a genuine attempt to compensate for five half- eaten meals and the lost patronage from a group of people who appreciate inventive, tasty, food served properly
author: sheryl f.

description:
I'm really torn. The choice of wine and other drinks were top notch, however the food was awful. 

I had one of the flatbreads, my wife had the mac'n'cheese and both were completely over peppered to being inedible. Even a couple of bites managed to ruin the wine. 

So yea for the place and drinks
nay for the food
author: Jonathan S.

description:
Only complaint - no room to wait for a table! Felt a little bit like we were partaking in a human slide-puzzle.

Ordered:
Malbec - fantastic, they also have wines on tap, which is pretty neat
Sage Capter Butter - really great way to start off a meal, love the homemade bread too. Can't wait to come back and try other flavors!
Cesar Salad w Fried Capers - really large, very tasty. We needed it with all our savory food!
Pot Pie - also very large, delicious - reminds me more of chicken & dumplings

If you come with another person, share everything - portions are too large to order on your own.
I will be coming back! Can't wait to try the homemade pretzel!
author: Cristina M.

description:
Brick walls, chandeliers, teeny tiny. Feels like a bit of New Orleans in SF. They were extremely patient accommodating of our large, drunk (coming off of karaoke) group of friends who changed seats and tables like musical chairs (as a former waitress this always makes me cringe). 

All I need to say: Butters. There is a category on the menu. For Butters. Get them all. Share. Swoon.
author: Melissa G.

description:
The proximity of this gastropub to my house definitely ups the ratings a bit, but they could hold their own even if it was farther away.

I end up stopping by this place more often than not when going out for drinks around my area. They have excellent bites (even dinner if you want a meal there) and a great beer and wine list. I had a sour beer last time that was really delicious:
Echte Kriekenbier Brouwerij Verhaeghel  6.8%  
Flemish Red Ale (Cherry),  BEL (330ml)

I looked up the name so all of you can try it and enjoy the deliciousness.
author: Raina B.

description: Such a nice athmosphere! I love the decor. Huge selection of beers. Great service. Didnt try the food but it looked delicious. Will definitely come back!
author: Ellen Cecilia S.

description:
Share all the food!

Gastropub.  What does that actually mean?  Who came up with that term? I'll have to do some research because... they are awesome.  Cheap pub fare with a gourmet spin.  Extra special brews and wines.

Fat Angel is such a gem in this Alamo-Western Addition neighborhood.  It's a pretty small space, not good for large parties.  There's a bar area and a heated outdoor patio.

homemade BUTTERS. small plates to share-- cheeses, meats, olives and nuts. these are clearly of the highest quality-- ask for extra bread if you get the butters!  They also have 3 or 4 salads (which could easily serve 3, not exaggerating) and a few mains.  My BF ordered the chicken pot pie which was SO COMFORTING AND DELICIOUS. even to a vegetarian.  I had the apple walnut gorgonzola endive salad. Fresh. 

Wines on tap. Good wines on tap.  A beer list 5 pages long.  For the beer enthusiast.

Came here to do some celebrating late monday night and they were full.  This place gets packed on the weekends.  Friendly staff, pitchers of water on the table.
author: Tiffany W.

description:
I've stopped in a few times to grab a few beers and a bite to eat before heading to concerts at the Fillmore.  They feature both beers and wines on tap, and have an incredibly extensive bottled beer list.  The prices can be rather high, but the selection is worth it, as they have many imported and unusual beers to sample.  The bartenders have been great about letting one try a sip of the on-tap beer or wine first, before ordering a full glass, and are happy to make recommendations from either tap or bottled lists.

I've only tried appetizers / share dishes, which were quite good as well.  I've yet to try the flatbread pizzas but they always smell and look delicious when I see them ordered at other tables.  It does seem like it takes a very long time to get warm dishes, such as the pizzas, though.  

My only complaints about this establishment are that they are constantly overwhelmed both in terms of service and space.  Service for food items is very slow, and there never seen to be tables free -- even rarely 2 adjacent seats at the bar.  They wind up with people milling around the bar without a place to sit or stand.  Not good at all for groups, and a bit of a risk on weekend nights, as you may have to wait a very long time to be seated.
author: Heidi M.

description:
So sad.  I normally love interesting wine bars like this, but really bad service can ruin anyplace.  Consider Fat Angel ruined.

Add: The owner contacted me and seems very nice and genuine.  Everyone has an off-night.  I'll bump them up a star and give them another shot sometime soon.
author: Zac A.

description:
Wine on draught! 

This place, I tell ya. When it comes to the cozy and classy, it doesn't get much better. The service was also exceptional, especially considering our larger group and my personal indecisiveness. So friendly.

I didn't try much of the food except the butter and bread. Just get it and love it. It looks like a great place for small plates, cheese, etc.

If I lived in SF, this would be my go-to date night place. It's casual enough to keep things light, but actually very romantic. What could be better than plying your date with wine and herbed butter by the spoonful?
author: Annie D.

description:
There was an Angel was always drunk.
So he didn't have wings
That was why he was a 2nd class 
His name was Clarence

So Joseph was like, "Hey Fatso! 
You Fatty Angel 2nd class!
You are FXXXin' 293 years old with no wing, Goddamn sonofabitch!

So Clarence was like, "What? Are you talking to me? You talking to me? What did you say, Jackass? FXXX off !"

So Joseph said, " I am just sick and tired of seeing your FXXXin' Fat stomach sticking out and drunk like a fish every day. I can't take it anymore.
So, Go help Gorge Bailey so I can get you wings. OK? Jackass?"

So Clarence was like, " Oh Shit! I blew it. I wanted stay like this until I get 300 but guess not. OK Jo the Jackass, I'll go down there to jump off from the bridge for the idiot."

So Joseph said, " Go Now! Gorge is ready to jump off!"

That should be what was going on in the original story or behind the scene of " It's a wonderful life."


But our real scene was to celebrate that my GF got a new job.
Today was her last "FREE" day Sunday.
So we went to see a movie, Midnight in Paris at Kabuki and we loved it.
After watchin' great movie together, we always get something to drink.
We went to Fat Angel.
The place is just wonderful.
So many great wines & beers on tap.
Yes, wine on tap!
We loved this place, small, cozy, clean, price was good, wine was very good, beer was so good, food was good, nice service.
We'll be back for sure.  

Lower Fillmore is getting better.

Even the Dirty Harry won't say, VFW, very few white disrict anymore.

It's just strange seeing Panda Xpress and Popeye's through the window.
author: Nobu K.

description: So this place is really crowded and the tables are teeeeeeny, so getting a table for more than two people is a pain.  The salami and spread with bread are delicious and just melts in your mouth.  The chicken pot pie is delicious and the way they do it is unique and different in a refreshing way.  The mac and cheese is really cheesy, but would be better if it were a lot less peppery.  Service felt a little slow, but all in all, this place is satisfactory.
author: Christine W.

description:
Fat Angel is pretty packed and crammed when packed with outdoor and bar seating. The ambiance is nice and lively though. Their alcohol, especially beer selection is amazing and wine on tap sounds super cool! 

The food is just okay though, typical wine/bar food. I tried the Maple Bacon Butter, which is smokey and delicious but the bread that just comes with it was disappointing. It crumbles when spreading the butter on top of it. I also had the Wild Mushroom & Truffle Oil Flat Bread--super earthy and salty. The flatbread was a bit too dry like cracker. The Mac n' Cheese smells and tastes super cheesy. It as yummy!
author: Mandy C.

description: I must say that although this was an after hours decision, I have every intention of coming back as soon as I can. We ordered the HUGE creme brulee and a bottle of wine to enjoy alongside. It was decadent, but most of all, I enjoyed the intimacy of the place. Great date spot, or spot to go to with a friend for a "catch up". I liked the look of it, being something like a French cafe that I'd been to when I lived in Paris. I can't wait to go back for some of the comfort food.
author: Brianna S.

description:
There's a trend going on, did you notice it?  What's with all these gastropubs sprouting all across the city, and WHERE were they before?  How come it took so long for some people to realize we love our booze and foodz?

In comes, Fat Angel, tucked away in what seems to be a thriving neighborhood compared to yesteryears.  And with a wide selection of beer, it may be the Western Addition's very own version of dare I say it, Monk's Kettle.  However, Monk's kettle will always have a place in my heart, but Fat Angel will be the neighborhood's finest.  

With a nice intimate spot and dim lighting with a good size bar, Fat Angel offers more than what it looks.  The beer selection on tap may be smaller, but they carry some amazing beers on bottle.  I was able to try some of the IPA from San Diego, but will definitely come for more other ones.  

And sitting outside with the heat lamps has its perks as there was a jazz  dance happening right across the street.  Quite a spectacle.  And the food, the food was great compliments to the beer.  Between my buddies and I, we enjoyed every single bit of it

-Flat Bread with Wild Mushroom and Truffle - amazing.  Almost like a simplified pizza, but the truffle and mushrooms make this.
-Salamate with Truffle - yes I like truffle, but on everything, I'm all game for.  We had the meat plate and this was definitely the best amongst the other ones which were good too.
-Pot Pie - good crisp and flaky crust with an amazing flavorful filling with tender chicken.
-Sliders - probably the only thing I could have skipped on, but it was good.
author: Vincent K.

description:
One of the best "old world" beer selections in SF. Knowledgeable staff, great food and exceptional decor. It is a must for the beer-lover.

2 small critiques: (1) the bread that was served with the delicious hand-churned butter was a little stale. (2) the sliders were dope except that the meat was poorly prepared and seemed like cheap meat put onto a gourmet soul slider.

BUT, the smoked trout salad was succulent and the staff was on their game.
author: Aaron C.

description:
I have to say I love this spot.

I checked it out for the first time a couple weeks ago with a friend. They have an excellent selection of different beers and wines. Kudos on the nice selection of sours. I am definitely on a sour beer kick. The bartender was very helpful as we selected four different beers to split. Love the sweet and sour beer, but stay away from the wild berries under sours. It tastes like cough syrup. Bleh.

Food: Can't complain here either. Food was solid and tasty. The caesar salad is huge! Comes in a giant wooden bowl. Enough for three or four people. We also had the mac n cheese, sliders, and the pretzel. 

Lastly, my favorite part. The ambience. It's a quaint neighborhood spot. Not pretentious. Great place to have a beer and a snack with a date or an old friend.
author: Aleyna S.
